text: Ar: Cocoa and dark caramels; treacle, cherry, and black pepper, all at medium-low intensity; a bit of hay. Ap: Deep brown, opaque; medium-large tan head with very good retention, leaving a web of foam as it subsides but retaining a thick, frothy cap of medium and small bubbles. T: Licorice, bourbon, and tar up front; rich dark chocolate and raisins, some rum spice; black currant and treacle; bitterness is medium, very herbal; medium sweetness throughout. P: Medium-full body with medium-high carbonation; finish is medium-dry. O: Absolutely spectacular; one of the best bourbon-barrel-aged beers Ive had; all of the classic Baltic porter flavors--dark caramel, dried red fruits, and chocolate--mingle beautifully with the rich, spicy flavor of the bourbon.
Opaque black with a medium sized tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Roasty, smoke, vanilla, charred wood, and bourbon in the finish.

16.9 oz. bottle. Poured dark brown with a short lived off white head. No lace. Strong bourbon aroma with secondary chocolate, vanilla and oak tannin. Semi sweetness on the flavor. Everything in the nose is also present on the tongue. Pick up a hint of the brown sugar the label mentions. Bourbon notes keep the chocolate and caramel from being to sweet. Oats give the body smoothness. Medium bodied. This was nice!

From the .5 liter bottle with no date that I can see. It pours a deep dark brown to near black with a moderate tan head that fades. The Bourbon barrel aging is most evident in the aroma along with roasted dark malts, sweet dark bread, and a low to no hop profile. But if you are looking for some barrel-aged sensation you will not be disappointed with this one. The body is smooth and around medium. The sweet roasted dark malts can be found more so in the taste along with that slightly boozy barrel aging sensation that sticks with the palate from start to finish. And yet it maintains the sweetness of a good Porter. Nice job Jacks Abby.

Bottle via IP trade. Poured a medium to slightly fuller density of pitch black under an average sized tight foamy beige head. Aroma is a bit off. Light sour dark cherry notes are beginning to creep in over the dry dark chocolate and light woody bourbon. As the beer warms the sour disappears and some roasted coconut comes out. Flavor is very dry chocolate, light vanilla bourbon, wood, burnt toast, earthy. Fuller body, starts off syrupy but eventually it turns into an almost harsh dryness on the end. Nice once the sourness disappears.
Sweet, with a light Barrel character, it is still built like a brick sh#thouse. Big coffee and vanilla notes, medium length finish.

Gravity Cask Third of a Pint at GBBF 2014, Olympia, London Aug 2014 - Very Dark Brown/Black in colour. No head. Very Malty; roasty malts, dark chocolate, brown sugar, vanilla, oak, bourbon very evident. Fruity; dried fruits, raisins. Very smooth. Sweet roast malty and very chocolatey throughout. Enjoyed this a lot. Nice Baltic Porter! (2014-08-13)
On twp in nuc. Poured black with tan head. Aroma sweet malty vanilla. Light carb med bod. Taste sweet malty chocvanilla.

The Sampler, Brooklyn tap: pours black with beige head. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, and molasses. Light bitterness. Kind of sweet, but not too sweet. Nice aftertaste. Wish I had more but I killed the keg.

Bottle poured into a tulip..dark brown with a medium off-white head..aroma of
roasted nuts,coffee,bourbon,bread..taste
of funk,bourbon,nuts,bread..pass on this.

On tap @ Doc Ponds. Pours thick inky brownish black with thin mocha head. Aroma is big roasty dry dark chocolate malts, soy sauce. Rich, oaky, boozy mouthfeel, creamy smooth body, lovely barrel notes on the finish. Minimal bourbon or booze. Somewhat thin body as expected for a Baltic Porter. Rich flavor, but drinks much lighter than 10%.

500ml bottle. Dark brown with a frothy tan head. Flavors are vanilla, bourbon, almonds, roasted cereals, alcohol and chocolate with fruity and spicy notes. Full body, soft to moderate carbonation carbonation, creamy texture.

Tap at the source. Pours pitch black, big beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, minimal bourbon. Very mild bourbon. Blindfolded I wouldnt guess this is barrel aged. Chocolate, some vanilla. Flavor is chocolate, roasted malt, mild bourbon. At least that I can tell is there. Some vanilla, roasted malt, smoke. Crisp. Good for a Baltic Porter, just ok for barrel aged.

Bottle pours out black topped with a small tan head. Nose is nice big bourbon barrel notes some vanilla marshmallow cream roast and a rich roast. Taste is more of the bourbon barrel goodness vanilla chocolate some pit fruit sweetness and plenty of roast.

Draught at the brewery, 4/23/16.For the record, my friend and I both had our own separate 6oz pours (the largest size) of every variant. We could have split a sampler rack of 2ozers, but thats not how I role.Light bourbon in the nose, very light. Nice. More wood and light bread and bitter chocolate. Liquorous, but not boozey, at least not at the start. Spicy whiskey notes are enjoyable and balanced, with a touch of coffee and more chocolate. Really nicely even and spread out amongst different aromas in the nose. Its neither too malty, spicy nor roasty.Light vanilla, some very dry bread and bitter chocolate form a vacuum, body-wise and it seems just a bit thin and over-attenuated at times. But nutty tannins as well as some caramel build, especially with warming. Spicey and quite whiskey/bourbon-like though without any dominance in that category. I like that it ends on the dry side with a slick-to-chewy texture and ample, engaging, low carbonation, to-boot. Good stuff and not overdone on the barrel, as with all of the recent variants. Im willing to bet the coffee and vanilla versions are more balanced now, as well, though I havent tried them recently. Fun to try alongside the port, double and regular versions. But the candy and brandy-character of the port version was the winner for me (as is usually my preference). Good stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2016 Black pour with a thumbs worth of head. Aroma is pretty much all bourbon whisky. Whisky dominates the taste up front, some vanilla, caramel, fairly sweet and boozy like a Jack and coke.  some hop bitterness creeps up in the finish.  Medium body.
From a bottle at the DC gathering May 1, 2016. Pours a clear cola brown with an ecru head. Flavors of caramel and bourbon. Roast finish.

2 oz pour on draft at Jacks Abby. Consumed on 4/21/2016. Bourbon barrel aged. 2016 release at 10.6% ABV. Dark brownish black with tan head. Aromas of oak, dark chocolate, dark fruit. Tastes of dark chocolate, oak, whiskey, dark fruit. Medium body with a dry finish. Pretty good.

Bottle from Julios. Labelled as "Bourbon Barrel-Aged". Poured into a snifter. A very dark opaque brown color with a frothy tan head that settles to a thin lace. Sweet bourbon and sugar aromas. Vanilla, coffee and chocolate notes. Silky texture. Boozy in the middle. Long sweet finish with decent bitterness.

Draught @ As Is NYC. Dark brown with slight reddish tint, small foamy beige head, strong coffee aroma with alcohol, low carbonation, slightly sweet mocha taste with a bit of fruity-woodsy flavor, long mocha finish with alcohol aftertaste. Very chocolatey and impressive.

The beer is nearly black, but you can see some dark brown in smaller quantities. Not super dark. Light brown head. Decent retention, not much lacing. Big on milk chocolate in the aroma. Decent amount of oak. Medium vanilla. Fairly strong caramel at the base. The barrel comes through with just a touch of heat. Taste has a lot of that light vanilla-caramel-milk chocolate sweetness. Nice toasty sugars. Not much roastiness at all. Just some fruity roast flavors in the background. Medium sweet but its not a heavy sweetness. Fairly light feel for 10% abv. A bit creamy. Easy to drink. Solid.

Bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small creamy lacy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, bourbon, vanilla and oak. Flavor was smooth and slightly sweet with chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, caramel, brown sugar and oak. silky texture, medium body, dry roasty finish.

Oak, coffee aroma, dark brown/black color, brown head, coffee, licorice, chocolate flavor, medium to full body, warm alcohol finish that dissipates off the tongue

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draft at Jacks Abby. Pours a deep brown to black color with a thin rim of tan head. Aroma is slightly boozy, vanilla, molasses, bourbon. Boozy flavor. Good for sure, but I like the variants better.

Thanks to Maxbier for sharing. Pours Black with cream colored head. Roasted malt aroma with vanilla, chocolate and bourbon. 
 Flavor is dark roasted malt, brown sugar, caramel, vanilla, oak and bourbon. Sweet roasted malt finish. Fantastic brew.

Bottle from source. Dark dark brown with thin brown head. Aroma of vanilla roasty malt and hints of bourbon. Flavor is smooth vanilla, bourbon roast and hints of coffee. Some dark chocolate. Worth the hour in the car, should have bought two bottles (or 10).

Bottle, 2013 thanks to cocoapuph! Pours opaque black, small tan head, dissipates with nice residual and lacing. Aroma is bourbon, molasses, anise, cocoa, vanilla. Flavor is light sweet and light plus bitter, lots of bourbon with oaky notes and a backdrop of molasses and anise. Medium body. Solid.

Well barreled. Caramel and light oak. Some bourbon. Black pour with decent mocha head. Light sweet finish. Some booze. Sweet finish with touch of oak astringency. Well balanced but not a lot to this one. Tap at brewpub.

2014 Bottle from the brewery. Big bourbon nose, vanilla, lots of chocolate. Almost black, orange tints. Lots of bourbon barrel flavor, chocolate, some berries. Soft, silky, nice little carbonation. Bourbon takes over a bit too much, but delicious.

Sample on tap at the brewpub. Deep brown black pour with thin off white head. Aroma is very boozy, intense bourbon, scotch notes light meaty saline aromas. Taste is smoky salty sweet and woody. Palate is med-full bodied with med-light carbonation. A bit whisky heavy.
Malty flavour, beige head. Aroma of vanilla, malts, oak and caramel. Bitter flavour, coffee, cacao, vanilla. Finish coffee, malts, bourbon and chocolate. Nice!(from draught -cask- @ GBBF 14, London)
Bottle. Aroma of vanilla, wood, licorice. Taste is silky smooth chocolate, vanilla, vanilla, coffee, bourbon, and vanilla. Good.
Black pour from bottle at home, got this in a trade. Vanilla and cream, cocoa. Whiskey finish. Super tasty beer.
Strong vanilla and bourbon notes. Tastes sweet and And really vanilly. More like a stout then porter. Pours brown with a thick cream head. Had a bottle share a kasers.

Cask (gravity) @ GBBF 2014, Great British Beer Festival, London Olympia, Hammersmith Road, London, England W14 8UX. [ As Jacks Abby Barrel Aged Framinghammer Baltic Porter ].Clear dark black color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is heavy malty, chocolate, wood, vanilla, alcohol - bourbon - vanilla, moderate roasted. Flavor is heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long duration, sweet chocolate, roasted and chocolate bitter, coconut - barrel - bourbon - wood. Body is medium to full, texture is creamy to watery, carbonation is flat to soft, finish feel is moderate alcoholic. [20140812]
This poured a darker brown with a beige head. Aroma was of light roast and dry chocolate. Flavor similar, but very restrained, but not really complex, not really any barrel either. Meh
Pours a dark brown with no real head. Aromas of dark fruits and chocolate fudge. Light vanilla. The taste is too much like a lager to me and this yeast is t helping the beer. Just not digging it.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2015 Draft at Pony bar HK with Brendan. Pours a deep chocolate brown body with thin lacing. Aroma is rich chocolate brownie. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of sweet chocolate fudge, brownie, bourbon barrel and light alcohol. Nice.
On tap at coalhouse pizza. The bourbon makes this boozy. Sweet and spicy.some thick lace. A sipper.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with very tiny tan looking head. Aromas of sugar, chocolate, and bourbon. Flavor had chocolate, vanilla, wood, and bourbon burning. Full body and a thick silky texture. Average carbonation and burning alcohol finish. Not bad.

Thanks J! Pours very dark brown with a small deep tan head. The smell is milky, chocolate, bourbon, wood, alcohol. The taste is vanilla, chocolate, drank fruit, licorice some dry roastiness on the end. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Nice!
Many thanks to Rian for sharing! Nice woody nose, hints of vanilla, wood, nice round smooth. Woody-vanilla nose, fresh smooth, nice round malty-smooth bitter vanilla. round and great!
Runder malziger, angenehm holziger Antrunk. Die Alkoholigkeit ist leicht und noch angenehm. Wenig herb, leicht vanillig. Nett. 10/11/10/11/10/11

Thanks Chris for generously giving this to me a few months ago. Sadly, stored at fridge temp the whole time so I dont know if it changed too much. split 2 ways at 38F in stemware. Pours pitch black, 1 finger coffee colored head that faded quickly. Not a lot of barrel presence in the aroma. coffee, nutmeg, clove, cinnamon and brown sugar aroma with fudge. Whoa, the bitterness is insane...must be over 150 IBUs..seriously like this is insanely bitter and that totally masks the chocolate, coffee and whiskey presence. Not a terrible beer but simply not what I was expecting compared to last years adjunct variants.

Draft at Bierstube during a Philly Beer Week event. Tulip. Opaque black pour with a tuft of khaki foam that left an impressive sheet of lace at the top (though someone next to me was drinking the same thing but there was no lace at all). Very lactic Baltic Porter. Big liquorice flavors. Dark roasted malts. Charred oak planks. Expected coffee/chocolate flavors are present but not defining. Burnt carob cake. Some Scotch Ale flavors - vegamite, artichokes, celery hearts and peat. Proved to be a clear dark brown color by the bottom of the glass. Thinking that this beer starts off great and could prove fantastic if it had some more interesting Stout notes (leather, vinyl, charcoal, cigarettes). It finishes too abruptly. Suspect that it us the lager base smoothing out too many extraordinary flavors. So, in this case, the lager underneath mutes/deadens the palate and restrains the possibilities.

Bottle split with the wife from one of my many sources. Pours the part with a thin tan head. Light oak, bourbon nose. Taste has light smoke, faint espresso, light barrel treatment. Pretty subdued. Medium body.

Bottle from Meditrina. Black with lasting tan head and lace. Woody chocolate bourbon vanilla apple and earthy aroma. Very sweet per style chocolate earthy some ash hints of raisin vanilla wood with woody mild bitterness. Cloying, sweet, creamy. If I liked Baltic porters I might like this. But I dont.
A little light on the nose, but very big on flavor. Roasty, a little sweet, a little chocolate, balanced with just the right amount of hops.

Bottle - Thinner black pour with nice off white head. Nose of roast, chocolate, and vanilla. Taste is more chocolate than vanilla and the typical metallic taste with the style is not as pronounced. Good stuff.

500mL bottle shared by Chalemeaux. Thanks TJ! Cant believe I never rated this. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is dark chocolate, bourbon, vanilla oak. Flavor follows. Dark chocolate, coffee, mild bourbon, oak.
Poured from bottle dark black with one finger tan head. Aromas of bourbon fig chocolate and mild oak. Taste is rich smoky chocolate caramel and and lingering bourbon finish. Very nice beer.
Bottle shared by Bruce. Taste is chocolate, peanut butter and some roasted oak. The beer is great.

Bottle shared by my friend Bruce. Pours near black with an attractive tan head and a treacle aroma. There is a rich smoky dark molasses and anise flavor with a very bourbon finish. This beer is delicious.

Tasted on draft at barcode. Poured dark with tan head. Has a alcoholy taste to it but is smooth

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Great Porter. Inky black color with off white head. Taste of near coffee notes and smooth mouthfeel.

Pours a three finger light tan head that fades slowly leaving a good lace. Black color, no highlights. Good carbonation and medium-heavy bodied. Roasted malt nose and flavor follows with roasted malts and hints of hop bitterness. Light bitter aftertaste. High ABV is hidden. $3.70 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.
500ml bottle pours a thick black color without much head. It's of flavor in this. Medium sweetness, lots of chocolate, nice balance of hops. All the flavors come together well.

Appearance: Pours dark brown with a decent tan head that fades to a pin stripe around the edges.

Aroma: Dark chocolate, port wine, fig, bourbon.

Taste: Dark chocolate, peppery hops, grape. Finishes with a nice touch of bourbon.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied, silky, modest carbonation.

Overall: One of the best Baltic Porters Ive ever tried. The malts and barrel treatment worked perfect together, not too boozy or rich, but definitely decadent.

375, capped. Thanks, D! Very cool treat for sure. Pours an opaque black with a dense and creamy tan head that sticks around. Big forward, well-framed chocolatey note thats very clear, blended nicely with some apricot and a bit of oak. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Great combinations of roasty sweet chocolate and barrel character on the mid palate. Mild sweet finish. Very nice and drinkable.

From cask. Pours hazy dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is fruity, vanilla and wooden. Light caramelish. Bitter and roasted, dark malty, chocolate. Dark roasted and lingering dark malty finish.

This is a delicious smelling beer. Oak and bourbon dominate the bouquet but some doughy malts and vanilla sneak in there as well. It pours a cola brown with a small foamy light brown head that dissipated quickly. Flavor wise this is easily the best beer Ive had from Jacks. It is heavy on the oak and booze up front with some vanilla and brown sugar in the finish followed by more of that woody oak character in a dry finish. I think I would have enjoyed this beer even more if it had better mouth fell but this beer feels thin like any other lager and the juxtaposition between that thin mouth feel and those huge tasty flavors is a little unsettling and hard to comprehend. I would still say this is a very solid brew but dont expect something BCS caliber.

Bottle from a trade with WillRunForBeer. Pours dark brown color with light brown head. Aromas of bourbon, chocolate, roasted malt and oak. Big bourbon flavor up front with chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, and oak. Medium to full body with minimal carbonation. Very nice. Thanks Brian.

A- an opaque cocoa black pour with cola edges. Virtually no head or lacing. S- a lightly decadent inhale with vanilla accents. Some rhubarb, raisins, minerals, and tootsie rolls. Chocolate is there but somewhat plastic. Earthy as it opens up. Cacao tang, leather, soggy coffee grounds, molasses and some charcoal. A light peat and herbal quality. M- a medium oily body with no carb. Goes down fairly smooth. T- tootsie rolls again hold court with some coconut in tow. However, cheap Easter chocolate, vanilla, coffee and a mild alcohol burn set the pace. There is some meaty nuttiness to give it weight.  Zinc, bitter twigs, rhubarb, hearty sour oak are next. Lemons, grass and hops wrap it up without much fanfare.

Dark beer with only the faintest brown highlights when held against the light. Thin foamy brown head. Sweet molasses and alcohol wet wood in the nose. Big sweet flavor with tons of dark brown sugar and molasses with a nice whiskey bite. Vanilla, oak, some butterscotch, burnt caramel corn, dried rum soaked fruit, and a nice alcohol finish. It is a little bluntly sweet, but still a pretty complex barrel aged beer.
Bottle. Dark cola brown with ruby hues. Boozy oak aroma. Taste follows with sweet brown sugar and light citrus. Creamy mouthfeel, low carb. Excellent.
Bottle. Dark cola color with almost no head. Aroma is roast, burnt caramel, vanilla and wood. Taste adds brown sugar, oak and substantial booze. Slightly thin mouthfeel and medium carb.

Dark sienna, almost black and mostly opaque pour. Earthy, leathery oak and booze barrel initial nose. Mineral notes and acrid green pepper skins. Chocolate and wooden sherry-like oxidized colors are consistently present, though in a way somewhat befitting the style in my opinion. Its earthy depth, in burnt caramel and bonfire and bark, and warmth of composition are also appropriate. Alcohol is a little overbearing; there is a surprising absence of dark fruit character, but for some Concord grape.

Super dense, Caribbean rum high grade cacao flavor. The bourbon flavor is never overwhelming here, presenting its vanilla, toasted coconut and butter toffee notes in slow parade. Dried and dark fruit flavors of black mission fig and black cherry, though quiet, are more informative here than in the aroma. Maple syrup and dry oak remain prevalent; still earth and leather and forest themed.

OIly mouthfeel with a tiny prickle of carbonation and thats all. The rich malt layering and balance of tempered heat makes for a luxurious but highly drinkable texture. It is often easy to forget that this is even a barrel-aged beer, and its stylistic integrity independent of this fact is firm. Relatively clean finish with a lingering effect of oak, molasses, sherry. Never stunning, but thoroughly excellent.

Cask gravity @ GBBF 2014. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty woody chocolate and bourbon aroma. Roasted malty woody bourbon and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty woody bourbon chocolate and caramel finish.

Roasty,cocoa, dark fruit aroma. Pours black with a thin tan head that leaves a thin coating on the glass. Very smooth. Velvety mouthfeel. Boozy warmth. Cocoa, malty, prunes, raisins. Lots of warming in the throat. Very nice.

bottle. nose if chocolate and booze. a light bit of licorice. pour is dark brown with a garnet highlight. taste is a lot of thick, dark chocolate and booze. I wouldnt call this a Baltic porter, but more of an imperial porter. a tad fruity with a bit of alcohol warming/hotness in the finish. pretty good boost juice

Bottle as a ridiculous extra in trade. Big thanks! Pours dark brown from the bottle and settles essentially black and opaque in the glass with a small khaki brown head. Aroma is definite whiskey, caramel, vanilla, oak, some marshmallow. Flavor starts with dark fruits, chocolate covered raisins, whiskey, charred oak, long finish of char and vanilla. Pretty smooth but seemingly not a lot of rich flavor coming from the malts. Body is silky smooth, medium plus but perhaps not quite enough to handle the barrel, with low plus carbonation. Solid beer, but not sure I get all the hype Ive heard about this and its variants. Certainly a good beer, but the bar is pretty high for BA stuff these days.

Tasting at Matts Black color with large beige head. A good beer, but compared to the un-barreled version this one is less characteristic, it loses the bread character that makes the base beer great, it adds some vanilla and liquorice.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2014, London (13/08/2014) - black coloured pour with tiny tan head. Aroma and taste is roasted slightly burned malty, big chocolate, treacle, burnt brown sugar, some dark fruits, wooden notes, nice sweet and bitter balance, a big boozy warming bear hug at the end. Superb.
Had this at a little mini tasting. I dont remember much about it which isnt a good or bad thing.
Stunning Baltic. Barrel-aged infuses a nice flavor, without getting in the way too much with the base porter. Slightly boozy, would definitely benefit from aging.

Gravity at GBBF 2014. Poured a very dark brown, with a thin tan head. Aroma of rich oak, leather, port and molasses. Big brown sugar in the flavour, with sherry and hay. Finish was rich, with cherry, burnt malt and warming booze.

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black (dark brown) with low to no beige head. Aroma is of bourbon, chocolate, coffee, vanilla. Taste is of bourbon, vanilla, oak, roasted malt, alcohol, bitterness. Palate: Full bodied. Soft carbonation. Overall: Pretty good. Heavy stuff. Very intense on bourbon.

Cask at GBBF 
Dark brown with a medium sized tan head, some lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and molasses. Flavors of roasted malts and chocolate 
Very nice.

Cask at GBBF 2014, 12/08/14. Pours very dark brown/black with a tan head. Boozy aroma with liquorice, grass and treacle. Medium to full body, light carbonation. Rich with chocolate, rum, dark fruits, light citrus... Lovely balance - booze is in just the right place. Nice.

500mL bottle, pours a deep dark brown / black with a small beige head. Aroma brings out a good deal of vanilla, followed by bourbon and light roasted malt. Flavour brings out a lot of vanilla, followed by bourbon, light cocoa and a little roasted malt. More complex, with more vanilla notes and less roasted notes than the non-BA version. Great stuff.

Bottle courtesy of Summer Santa 2014. Thank you! Pours dark wooden brown with a rather small frothy and fizzy mocha head that doesnt leave much trace while dissipating. Smell is malty with roasted malts, caramel, butterscotch hard candy, toasted oatmeal flakes, dark chocolate, dark roast coffee, hay, charred wood and hints of toasted coconut, smoke and bourbon vanilla. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter and malty with roasted malts, burnt caramel, butterscotch hard candy, vanilla fudge, charred wood, toasted coconut, toasted hazelnuts, hay, oatmeal cookies, liquorice fudge and hints of smoke. Mouthfeel is soft, round, tiny viscous, tiny boozy and medium to full bodied. finish is sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, burnt caramel, butterscotch hard candy, vanilla fudge, oatmeal cookies, charred wood, bourbon, hay and hints of smoke and alcohol. Really elegant and tasty!

(Bottle) pours dark brown to black with pale nougat coloured head. The aroma holds buttery and spicy oak, chocolaty, bread-ish and light smokey malt, noble hops, sugar and grain. The flavour is light sweet, light to medium bitter and tiny acidic with notes of balanced oak, friendly roasted malt and traditional hops. The mouthfeel is smooth, clean yet somewhat tight with a light to medium carbonation. Malty finish. Medium bodied.

Cask at GBBF, 2014. Black pour, no head. Peat laden aromas of dark chocolate, oak, burnt wood and raisin. Warming flavours of chocolate, raisin and smoke. Dry, long alcohol burn fuelled finish. Very nice indeed.

Sampled @ GBBF. Opaque pitch black color, small light brown head. Aroma and taste are malts, heavy roast, heavy bourbon, lots of chocolate, warming alcohol, bitterness. Medium to full body, medium carbonation. Wow, heavy!

Cask at Great British Beer Festival 2014, Olympia, London. A black coloured pour with a thin beige head on top. Sweet, boozy, chocolate aroma. Tastes similar, slightly roasty, rich, sweet, boozy, chocolate, some vanilla.

bottle shared by tom10101, thanks bro. pours unclear very dark brown with a small light beige head showing minimal retention and lacing. very bourbony, chocolate-coated raisins, sweet caramelized and almost burnt nuts, booze, pepper, woody astringency, berry sweetness. moderately low carbonation, light to medium body - oily, assertive tannic-bitter coffee-mineral finish.
Bottle pours black with low head. Aroma is booze and roast. Taste is roast and bourbon, finish is medium bodied with a bit harsh alcohol

Bottle shared by tom10101, thanks! Pour is dark brown and is topped by a beige rim that leaves good lacing. Nose is of vanilla, rich chocolate and caramel. Quite decadent. Taste is pretty similar to BCBS or at least to what I remember of it (it has been a while) but less boozy, which is a good thing. Flavors are that of a nice dessert: sweet milk chocolate, vanilla, coconut and bourbon. Body is full, carbonation light and mouthfeel silky. Some hot alcohol but really not too much in fact. Really nice!

Bottle (500 ml). Thanks to Frank for this one! Dark brown with a small bubbly brown head and very little lacing. Aroma is dominated by bourbon, but theres also caramel, oak, chocolate and hints of vanilla. Taste is moderatelty sweet and, again, quite bourbon forward along caramel, vanilla, oak, chocolate and alcohol. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Warming finish. Good barrel-aged Baltic Porter, quite tasty and the alcohol is somewhat well hidden/integrated. The balance is far from perfect though, as the bourbon is taking too much place for my liking.
At GBBF 2014. Black beer no head. Bourbon. Lots of bourbon. Some chocolate. Bourbon. Fine. But too much bourbon for balance.
Cask at GBBF 2014. Aroma is lovely sweet vanilla, oak, orange, booze and choc. Flavour is rounded booze, orange, oak, vanilla. Palate is full and viscous warming alcohol in the finish. Really good.

Cask at GBBF 2014. Opaque black beer with a small brownish head. Vinous aroma, licorice, caramel, figs, raisins, chocolate, caramel, banana notes, plums, cocoa, vanilla, bourbon notes. Vanilla flavor, figs, raisins, dades, plums, licorice, chocolate, some cocoa and bourbon. Alcohol is incredibly well hidden. Full bodied and just amazing!!!
Cask - Chocolate, bourbon barrel vanilla and a slight boozyness. Jet black with a beige head. Chocolate and creamy boozy bourbon notes. Coconut and a warm fuzzy mouthfeel that makes me happy.

Bottle; Pour is murky brown, with a modest khaki head into this glass. It retains on the average / below average side, with light spotting presence. The nose is chocolate morsel, brown sugar, light vanilla barrel presence, with a hint of grain, moving to mild astringent from the base porter. The flavor profile is velvet grains, with a fairly heavy sweetness presence featuring the noted brown sugar and chocolate notes - with that kiss of vanilla from the barrel aging. Its bittering , with feint smoke, and a long lasting finish. Bravo - It was everything I was hoping for and more.

Aroma of bourbon and cocoa and vanilla. Taste is full flavored, slight sweet but not too much for an imperial. Very well balanced. This is actually quite amazing. Great bourbon flavors, great balance. Great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle: Thanks, Alex. Deep brown with a black center; a tan-leather, thin film outlines the top. Very nice barrel notes in the aroma; smooth bourbon & spicy oak with hints of tannin, vanillin, bittersweet chocolate, & faintly sweet dark prunes. Taste leans more towards the chocolate & dark fudge side, semi-sweet with a solid bit of bourbon warmth, wood, light maple syrup, & a touch of burn brown sugar in the finish. Body on the thinner side, but it still holds a nice, creamy element. Its only a porter, after all. A very delicious barrel aged lager.
500 ml. bottle. Pours almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of malt, bourbon, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is roasted malt, bourbon, dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee, and wood. Nice.

Bottle thanks to tectactoe for sharing. Dark brown pour with a tan foamy ring that lingers nicely. Aroma doesnt have as much barrel character as I expected but still had some great roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and vanilla. Tastes like chocolate fudge, dark chocolate, burnt wood, and vanilla. Some like bourbon booziness in the finish. Oily smooth. Really good beer. Nice subtle bourbon blends well with the base beer. Delicious.

Courtesy of tectactoe
Bottle: The aroma consists of coffee, chocolate, caramel, molasses, bourbon, and a touch of alcohol. It pours a dark brown with some faint orange highlights and a small beige head that quickly fades to a thin ring. The flavor starts with a chocolate, caramel, and a touch of molasses. The finish has light-moderate vanilla and light bourbon/whiskey. Its medium bodied with soft carbonation and a slightly creamy mouthfeel.
Sampled this at Tap and Mallet total tap takeover. Dark mahogany with dark biege head. Lots of peat, oak, smooth and lots-O-alcohol. Full body, mild carbonation, more peat, quite dry finish.

Bottle shared by b3shine. Poured a dark brown color with an average tan head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Good roasted coffee, chocolate and bourbon aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet toasted malt flavor with a medium to heavy sweet bourbon finish of moderate to long duration. Another very good porter.

Bottle @ Jack the Sipper. Deep brown with a small head. Deep roast. Sy coffee. Brown bread and some Nutella spread. Very similar flavour. Chocolate and toasted nut donuts. Chocolate nd ash. Full body, oily. Deems.

500 ml bottle shared by b3shine. Pours dark cola brown in color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor have rich roasted malts, chocolate, bourbon, wood, light coffee, coconut, vanilla and earth. Medium-bodied, lasting finish. Very good, but not blown away.

Bottle from Four Seasons. Pours coca-cola brown with a thin khaki head. Smells like malt and suntan lotion. Has a bit of oak on the tongue along with the molasses. Finish lingers a bit though it does hide its booze well. Solid but not something Id drink again.

500mL Bottle. I realize that my rating of this beer may come across as blasphemy, but I think theres some real homer, crowdthink going on with Jacks Abby beers lately, as Ive noticed some detectable brewing flaws that should have been commented on by other raters. I for one, dont think this is a very good beer. Noses heavy in booze, booze, booze, hot and raw bourbon. On the tongue, theres a complete lack of baltic porter base, instead bourbon alcohols ride over a sweet base and are joined by a distinct isovaleric, cheesy hop dominance, paired with a little tar and maple syrup. Out of balance from the barrel and marred by a distinct mid-palate cheesy hop note, this is not good barrel work and does nothing to improve the base beer.

500ml bottle. Thanks to b3shine for sharing. Mostly clear brown color. Thin ring of light bubbly khaki head. Slight red hue to the body. Great coffee, vanilla nose to this. Brown sugar. Moderate sweet taste, light bitter, light spiciness in the end, just a very light bit of alcohol warmth. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Light chewiness. Lightly dry finish. Pretty fantastic barrel aged porter.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the group). Looks good; a translucent dark brown with beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells solid; dark malt and oak. Tastes like it smells with a pleasant mouthfeel. Good, not great.

Bottle... Pours black with a small, creamy, taupe head. Good retention. The aroma is a luxuriant whirl of nuttiness, milk chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Full-bodied with a buttery mouthfeel and tickling carbonation. Deeply roasted, bitter, boozy flavor. Finishes charred with heavy bourbon. Bottle courtesy of landhoney!

Pours a hazy black with a thin mocha colored head. Nice aromas of deep roasted malt, chocolate and a light bourbon. Taste is pretty rich. Medium-to-heavy mouthfeel for style that allows the flavors to resonate for a while. Nice back-end sweetness goes along with a slight warming alcohol sensation. Very nice porter.
Pours an opaque dark brown. Aroma is oak and vanilla. Flavor is same with chocolate and wet tobacco. Finish is balanced, outstanding porter. Thanks for sharing, Shane!
At Jacobs with group. Pour is dark dark brown with most no head. Taste is smooth Baltic roasted malt, light chocolate and oak. Interesting Baltic porter, but not really mind blowing at all.

black color bottle to snifter..slight tan head..nose is wonderful with waves of real vanilla, coconut, bourbon..wow..mouthfeel is phenomenal with subtle coconut..tobacco..sweetness is easily kept in check with the malt and just a perfect amount of warmth and goodness from the bourbon barrel..lingers on the palate with that wonderful barrel character..complex to say the least..easily one of the best bourbon barrel aged offerings I have ever had and somewhat reminiscent of that bourbon cherry taste of the GI cherry rye..well deserving of recent awards..wonderful barrel aged offering..snatch up any that you see this exceeds the hype..
bottle shared by Skyview! pours dark with lots of roasted malts. Some wood and bourbon, preferred the vanilla version.

Pours an expected black... thin dark tan head leaves virtually no lacing atop a viscous brew... I do love my new CCB Teku.

Nose is clean dark malt, turbinado sugar, plenty of bourbon spiked by vanilla and oak.. something that reminds me of tawny port and dark cherry essence.... Pretty damn rich aromas.. weird oak smoke with warmth

Flavor marries all the aromas but doesnt quite deliver... seems a little flimsy.. definite rich brown malt with plenty of barrel presence.. Dark malt plays well, but is a 2nd fiddle with the bourbon barrels..

Body is pretty full.. light carbonation doesnt distract.. smooth.

Syndicate hooked this one up.. Thanks Darrel... I appreciate it my friend.

500ml bottle pours dark rich brown-black with tiny half finger tan head. Nose is earthy wet coffee, soil, soft raisin, booze. Taste is rich earthy roast malt, raisin, soft dark fruits, bitter chocolate, occasional sweet touches, dark coffee beans. Finish is bourbony fruit, roasty cocoa, touch of smokiness, raisin. Does get a bit boozy as it warms. Great!

Poured from bottle to glass. Dark black hue with brown head. Aroma is bourbon, vanilla, coffee, chocolate, roasted malt. Mouthfeel is good with a moderate body and light carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness with an astringent following and ethanol finish. Overall this is a good brew bug is a bit thinner than average.
Sweet stout with a bit of roast and with a bit of barrel notes. Nothing special really.
Bottle shared at LeviLOL tasting. Bourbon nose. Brown pour with a tan head. Good, kind of bitter in the finish.
Bottle shared by Bob - thanks! Deep brown pour with reddish highlights. Awesome bourbon and wood in this. Smooth, rich, and delicious.

Bottle as shown thanks to Clark. Pours a dark brown with beige head that lasts. The aroma is vanilla, oak, roast, and booze. Medium mouthfeel with dry caramel, roast, smoke, and nice light roasty finish. Very good
honestly dont remember much about this one, but i think it was an older bottle. will have to try a newer one soon.
draft at Blue Monk, wow!! very impressive beer. chocolate, roastiness, bourbon, vailla, oak. A ton going on but it all works together very well. wish i could get more

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2014 Échantillonné du Extreme beer fest 2014: Servie un peu trop froide et jai pas eu le temps de saisir toute lampleur des saveurs mais je remarque que cest assez croustillants malgré la robustesse du corps. Chocolat noir, espresso, vanille et petits fruits sont à lavant plan. Franchement facile à boire.

Draft at Blue monk. Dark brown pour with a thin light mocha head that settles around the circumference of the glass. Nose is oak, vanilla, roasted malt, Some booze. Taste is sweet up front, dark roasted malts , oak and some mild bourbon. Notes of vanilla and cherry in the finish.
Bottle thanks to beernut. Pours pitch black with small tan head. Taste is strong roasted coffee and vanilla. Really tasty. Another good one from beernut, thanks man!

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Aaron. Thanks man! Pour is deep brown with a frothy brown head and good lacing. Roasted malt, light coffee, caramel, toffee, bourbon, vanilla, pie crust, and grain in the aroma. Taste is cocoa, earthy, grassy, grainy, espresso, somewhat husky, and candi sugar. Slick mouthfeel with a soft carbonation. Nice Baltic Porter.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of big vanilla, dark chocolate, roast, hints of coffee, oak, bourbon, brown sugar and molasses, some spice. Taste is a mix of dark sugar, roast, coffee, hints of cocoa, hints of vanilla, oak, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.

Bottle thanks to a trade! Pours black with a creamy brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of roasted malts with a bit of chocolate, sweetness and a good amount of bourbon. Flavor has sweet dark grains with a good amount of chocolate and a much more subdued barrel note.

Pours dark, thick, and unclear blackish in color with a darker caramel head. Aroma brings sweet coffee and roasted malts. Flavor brings sweet creamy mocha and some smooth spicy booze, so easy and delicious on the palate.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2014 re-rate 06/14.....................bumped up from 4.2    Not sure how you get much better.  my favorite style.  aroma as below - wonderful.  sweetness of oats and sugars with roast and alcohol - a little better cold vs. warm.   wowwowo!!!                        Whoa!! Bottle from phatdog1?? Dated 03/13. Subdued aromas of bourbon wood roast and vanilla. Creamy smooth mouthfeel taste is DAMMMM good like aroma heat comes and goes better colder than room temp must find again. That is why I love this style

Sampled at the brewery during their second anniversary event. Pours near black with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, strong bourbon and oak, some chocolate, hints of vanilla, and a little dough. Flavor the same with a great blend of the dark beer and bourbon barrels. Smooth texture. A good beer.

Pours black with a small, quick diminishing brown head. Aroma is wonderfully complex. Vanilla, tobacco, bourbon soaked cherries, and plenty more. The sweet roasted malt leads to a pleasant alcoholic finish. Just the right amount of heat. Medium body that smooth. Great beer!

Very dark brown, beige lacing. Bourbon, oak, chocolate, coffee, toffee, and earth. Bittersweet chocolate taste. Smooth, a little more than medium-bodied with lively carbonation, but just a tad thin. Mild warming alcohol finish.

.5 liter bottle poured into a snifter. It pours a nice dark brown color with a good tan head. The aroma is pretty strong with nice sweet vanilla, caramel, cocoa and coffee. Very bourbon forward but not too much. Theres some brown sugar and dates in there as well. The flavor is a nice mix of burnt sugar, raisin, dates and vanilla, caramel and fudge. Very thick and silky on the palate. It has a smores-like finish with some coffee. I like this better than the standard version. The bourbon flavors bring the sweetness of the original to a new level.

Rcvd in trade last Spring. Consumed April 16, 2013. Review is from notes:
Bottled March 2013:
Into a pint glass.
The appearance is a dark brown/black colored body with a fingers worth of head that quickly dies and leaves a film of lacing sticking to the glass.
The smell has chocolate malts, light coffee, dark fruits (plum, raisins and figs - more or less...??).
The taste is sweet and bitter at different times through the previously mentioned flavors with added vanilla and bourbon, dry sweet aftertaste and finish.
On the palate its about a medium and smooth, wow, how smooth, probably one of the smoothest Baltic Porters Ive ever had. Alcohol is hidden well. Carbonation is right on the mark
Overall, wow, well balanced Baltic Porter that impressed me with some nice complexities that make it superior in its style.
Pours very dark brown with tan head. Smells and tastes of coffee and chocolate. Very good winter beer.
Pours black with a tan head. Aromas of coffee. Flavors of dark chocolate, bourbon and brown sugar.

Opened alongside as the Vanilla Framinghammer. Looks about the same, a bit less head. 

A bit of oak and bourbon on the nose among the roastyness. Boozy; strongly roasted, quite dry, spikes of booze here and there. Everything comes together reasonably well, yet it's a noticeable step down from the Vanilla variant. Nonetheless, I'd happily buy this if it were readily available.
Pours a dark brown with a thin chocolate colored lacing. The flavor is rather sweet and the aroma consists heavily of chocolate, soy sauce, bourbon and vanilla. The palate is slightly thin

bottle @the dmac Monmouth Park Horserace Gathering shared by whaleman THANKS Dave, nice meeting you too!-lt brown-mahogany. A-bourbon, sweet brown sugarmed malt. T-bourbon, wood, sweet brown sugar-med malt, 2nd herbal hop bite.

Served alongside the bourbon barrel aged with vanilla beans version. The beer is nearly black with an inch of mocha colored head. Nice aroma, featuring bourbon, oak, chocolate. Very tasty and quite smooth on the palate. Very tasty, though not as wonderful as the version with vanilla beans. Fairly low carbonation with alcohol content well hidden. A delightful beer to sip.

500mL at Woodshop 8. Pours a clear deep cola, with spotty lacing. Nose is awesome bourbon barrel, soft vanilla, no sticky tomato paste. Taste is excellent hazelnut, big roast, vanilla, rich fudge. Palate is beautiful- silky, soft, easy to drink. Loved.

Jacks abby has to have the ugliest labels .. . Pours a deep ruby brown .. . Mild foam .. . Light mouth .. . Molasses and burnt bran .. . Pretty good but lacks a backbone .. . . The batmobile is outside

19th September 2013The Last Tasting at Bruces palatial pad. Thanks to Leighton for this one. Opaque dark brown beer with a tidy pale tan head. Palate starts smooth, turns slightly crisp. Fresh tasting mellow dark malts. Nice touch of mellow barrelling and light fruity bourbon. Whisper of dark chocolate. Light minerally finish. Super mellow and drinkable.

Bottle split at Bruces pad, big thanks to Leighton for sourcing, 19/09/13.
Very dark mahogony brown with a thin off white head that dissipates edgeward.
Nose is chocolate, roast malt, toffee, bourbon is well evident.
Taste comprises sweet toffee, chocolate, brown sugars, subtle bourbon notes, light peppery spice.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, smooth on the palate.
Great drop, the alcohol is well integrated making for an easy drinking affair.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle at Bruces, thanks to Leighton. It pours dark brown with a tiny bubbly off-white head. The nose is soft roast, toast, cocoa, caramel, coconut, wood and sweet vanilla. The taste is roasted malt, toast, ash, liquorice, decent bitterness, caramel, burnt notes, spice, meatiness, chocolate, vanilla, toasted coconut and light alcohol (but not that of 10%!) with a dry, roasty finish. Well hidden-alcohol. Nice bitter-sweet aspect. Rather delicious!

Bottle at Bruces - London. Thanks to Laura for this one! Pours clear, deep brown with a slight, creamy tan head. Nose has some charred wood, subtle roast, cocoa. Medium sweet flavor, nice milk chocolate, sturdy roast, slight earthy bitterness, a bit of alcohol kick, mild dry wood, hints of vanilla. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly warming to finish with vinous, dry woodiness, dry cocoa, some barrel, dirt, hints of toffee, some burnt toast. Very nice beer.

500 ml bottle shared by bsuedekum- thanks again, Blake! Pours a deep coffee brown with a beige head. Aroma of chocolate, bourbon, coconut, earth, oats, and nuts. The flavor is the same, with more oak and toasted brown sugar. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a warming mouthfeel. Good, but didnt blow me away.

Rate from ann party in Vt. Bottle shared at best western session in Vt. Pours deep brown with beige head. Notes of roasty malt, vanilla, bourbon barrel, chocolate, and light ash. Medium to fuller body. Smooth and flavorful, nice porter.
Bomber as a bonus. Dark mahogany with dark biege head. Lots of peat, oak, vanilla, smooth, alcohol. Full body, mild carbonation, more peat, quite dry, great finish. Quite liked this.
Super dark brown pour with a cocoa colored head. Flavors of prunes, roast,charred oak, tar, bourbon and toffee. Thanks to the Palm Beach crew!
Bottle at Monmouth Park tasting. Pours very dark brown with tan brown head. Nose and taste of mocha, oak, smooth bourbon, vanilla, brown sugar and roast chocolate malt. Very smooth. Medium body.
Decent barrel notes, dark fruits, semi- clean, dark malts. It is a decent take on the style.

Bottle thanks to lukaduke. Pours a near black with a beige head of foam. Decent retention. Aroma is thick on the oak, vanilla, bourbon, then moves to a pleasant roasty, birch beer and marshmallow presence. Tastes sweet and boozy. Delicious stuff.
Maybe the value beer buy of the year..  Silky smooth roasty bourbon flavor.  Highly drinkable for 10%.   $6 for .5 liter, yes please.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Dark and almost fruit aroma with wood and bourbon tones. Flavor is rich and has some depth.
Bottle sampled in Exira, IA. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours a black color with tan head. Creamy, bourbon aromas and flavors. Tasty.

Opened my last bottle with mishuggah and thetomg after the Movement Festival in Detroit. Probably not the greatest time for a tick, but gonna give it a go regardless. Poured into a non-descript plastic cup. Pours black in color with the smallest amount of creme colored head, not even a half fingers worth. The nose is comprised of bourbon, toffee, chocolate, and vanilla. The flavor follows the nose, with the bourbon and toffee being more prominent. Moderate mouthfeel with some general creaminess and moderate carbonation. The finish lingers nicely with just a touch of booze.  Another really nice offering from Jacks Abby. Very drinkable barrel aged lager, would definitely like to have more bottles of this.
I smell alcohol, coffee and dark fruit. Out of a bottle and headless, direct light gives a crimson glimmer,. tastes fruity, more sweet than bitter but not overly, bourbon. clean finish

I picked up all three barrel aged variations at Julios Liquors on 4 May 2013. I am now comparing Side- by Side- by- Side.  Deep dark black pour, no light breaks through even when held to the sun. Nose gives off a nice oak, burnt wood and molasses. Awesome flavor of roasted malts, chocolate, sweet mellow bourbon and vanilla booze notes. Alcohol warmth lingers down the throat. The 10% is harsh at all. Its an unbelievable barrel aged beer that downs down really easy. Unreal brew!

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2014 Bottle @ Exira Beer Summit IV. Thanks to Ernesto987, I believe, for this wale. Pours a deep brown black appearance with a thin brown head. Very nice bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, caramel, light anise aroma. Creamy mouth feel. Fairly warm, a bit boozy. Deep chocolate cake, caramel, woody, slightly dark fruity, mild licorice flavor. Tasty stuff if you dont mind the bourbon.

black pour with a tan head. Big sweet bourbon nose and taste. slight sour notes cut the sweetness in a good way. Roasty coffee, some chocolate, banana, and a bit of caramel. Sweet finish, lots of barrel.
Bottle, pours black khaki head. Boozy sweet aroma. Taste is thick bourbon slight hop after taste
What a great beer. Really nice spicy vanilla bourbon notes accompanied by a great roasty milky porter backbone.  I love this brewery with the fire of 1000 suns.
500 ml bottle, great rich beer with sweet rich body, great barrel characteristics
Bottle. Poured a black color with an off white head. Wood, bourbon, dark fruits, vanilla, some chocolate, and caramel. Alcohol content overall well hidden.

Pour is oily black with a dark tan head. Nose is big and rich, roasty with light charred wood, rich dark chocolate and cake batter.  Taste is strong caramel, rich chocolate cake and light charred barrel. Dry finish, creamy body and soft palate.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2014 dark sepia, cream head, large bubbled. Nose is heavy roast, pretzel, and oat, light chocolate. Flavor is initially stinging chocolate, bit watery oat mid, toasted sugar and chocolate finish. Very balanced but too much sugar, palate soft to allow profile
Bottle.  Liked the tap version of the base beer better than the barrel aged version.  Clean complex character of the base beer somewhat muffled by a doughed bourbon vanilla presence.  Still good.

Ahh... Lager. 

Pours really, really dark for a lager... Even when held directly up to a light bulb only yields a little brown around the edges, not the usual red. Intense aromas of bourbon and oak. Rally meaty. Very round taste... Oaky and flavorful, while retaining a slight sweetness and a little boozy punch. Its quite good. Finishes with a lingering bourbon aftertaste that sticks in your mouth for ages. Nice. 
Another world class beer from what is quickly becoming my favorite brewery.

Pours a deep umber black color with a two finger of mocha foam head that sticks nicely. On the nose its rich sweet chocolate, coconut cream and nice vanilla and roasted malts. The palate is dialed into perfection when it comes to bourbon flavor... Perfect mouthfeel, smooth, creamy rich yet highly drinkable too. This beer is really speaking to me. Sweet, smooth boozy... Damn I cant stop crushing these !

NO WAY! 500 mL bottle purchased from Learys that I snatched for an excusable $5.50. To snifter it pours a deep rusted dark brown (black when up held to the light) with a trim, light yellow mustard head. Aromas of roasted pecans, raisins, booze, whiskey oak, lemongrass, sorghum molasses, cotton, black liquorice, American hops, Dutched chocolate, caraway seeds, and carob. Tastes simply astonishing: starts off with notes finely-ground espresso, dark chocolate/cocoa powder, and vanilla beans. From there, Im getting a lot of liquorice, carob, leather, and birch bark. Cocoa nibs, lager yeast, elderberry by swallow. Has an undercurrent of whiskey and booze. Unbelievably enjoyable.

Pours black into a tulip. Off-white head with medium retention recedes to hug rim. Sweet chocolate, vanilla and oak aromas. Thick with chocolate and bourbon upfront turning hot in the vanilla, espresso and oak finish. Nice.
500ml bottle. Pours dark black with very little head. Bourbon notes are very subtle along with the more pronounced malt and vanilla flavors. Very tasty brew, one of Jacks best efforts to date.

March, 2013 vintage. 500ml bottle into a tulip glass.

A - Pours a dark brown body thats bordering on black. Lets a little bit of light through but very little. Three fingers of super dense and creamy mocha foam upon pouring. Settles into thick edging. Sticky lacing with some solid retention.

S - Loads of sweet and rich milk chocolate up front give way to some light anise and roasted malts. Finishes with subtle but smooth vanilla and bourbon. A bit of alcohol heat.

T - Follows the nose with a predominately chocolaty flavor with light anise and roasted malts. Bourbon is again pretty modest here with some light vanilla, oak, and butterscotch. Alcohol is pretty noticeable but very pleasant.

M - Probably the best part of this beer. Not sure what kind of voodoo magic these guys pull, but the beer is rich and creamy...but at the same time its light and highly drinkable. Really fantastic.

O - This is a very delicious beer. I know Baltic porters tend to warp the line between ales and lagers, but I adore anything that Jacks Abby does and this is no exception. The fact that they are experimenting with barrels now is just too awesome. Plus the $6 price tag is super reasonable.

Pouring at the Saturday sessions of Extreme Beerfest.  Pours a deep brown to black with a faint white head.  Big bourbon on the nose.  Big and warm, bourbon and vanilla, cocoa and chocolate.  Warm brownies, bourbon and vanilla again.  Toasty oak and cocoa.

Sampled at EBF.  Pours a watery, translucent black with zero head.  Nose of licorice, vanilla, wood, malt.  Flavor is sweet, licorice, chocolate, caramel, brown sugar.  Full, sweet finish.  Fairly simple.

On tap at EBF 3/16/13.
Nice chocolate and light roast with hints of vanilla bourbon and oak. Smooth as hell and a pleasure to drink.

Tap at Meadhall for the Anniversary party.  Snifter  Very stil black pour with no head. Bourbon, roast, and faint caramel and vanilla make the nose. Taste is quite good. I know it's bourbon but the flavor reminds me more of dark rum.  Big time roast with just the right amount of booze. Not as much licorice as other Baltic Porters which works just fine. Sweetened black coffee flavor stays in the mouth Long with some alcohol warmth in the back of the throat. Nice beer...best in show tonight so far. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The pour is black in color with minimal head formation.  Starts off with some bourbon notes (wood, vanilla, etc.), followed by lots of roasted malt and dark chocolate.  A light fruitiness in the background.  The palate also features the bourbon nicely along with some notes of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt.  Fairly simple and straight forward, but really nice.
